bioghist.p: Professor Ross Johnston Wilhelm, a University of Michigan business economics professor whose commentaries on business and political issues were nationally syndicated, was born January 20, 1920 in Arlington, New Jersey. He married Rowena May in 1944.

Wilhelm received his BA and MBA degrees from Western Reserve, Cleveland, Ohio and his Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in 1963. Wilhelm was a Professor of Business Economics in the Graduate School of Business Administration at the University of Michigan.

His radio program, "Business Review" was heard from 1961 to 1981 on WUOM, and was nationally syndicated. He also wrote a column "Inside Business" which appeared regularly in more than 300 newspapers. Wilhelm received the University of Michigan Distinguished Service Award in 1963, and the Janus Award for the best business-oriented radio program in the nation in 1973.
Wilhelm died on March 22, 1983, at age 63.

scopecontent.p: The Ross Wilhelm papers (1925-1982) date principally from 1960 to 1982 and measure three linear feet. The papers document Wilhelm's radio program "Business Review" and other aspects of his professional career.

scopecontent.p: The Personal and Biographical material (1925-1982) primarily documents Wilhelm's teaching career at the University of Michigan. Included are photographs.

Portrait and contact photographs of Wilhelm; photographs of Wilhelm broadcasting WUOM radio program, with students and colleagues, and with family after receiving honorary doctorate from Eastern Michigan University (1977); and slides relating to excavations on Oak Island in Nova Scotia.

Professional Activities (1960-1982) contains the weekly commentaries Wilhelm gave on his radio show "Business Review." There are also essays and correspondence relating to a column, "Inside Business," that Wilhelm wrote for Business Roundtable, a non-profit organization in New York. Also included are various speeches Wilhelm gave and essays he wrote throughout his career.

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous includes notes and an article by Wilhelm on Oak Island, a small island in Nova Scotia where treasure was thought to have been buried. Also included are two folders of newspaper clippings regarding Wilhelm's economic forecasts and political views.
